column3: Where will cars be able to park in over crowded/over developed neighborhoods?
Will there be more public transportation options to get people out from the water front?
Will there be dedicated bike lanes so bikes don't have to go on sidewalks?
What if we had safe & healthy transportation alternatives? Cycletrack around Boston that connect EVERY neighborhood with low-stress bikeways.
Why doesn't the city implement cycletracks in our new and shiny Seaport Area? Northern Ave, Seaport Blvd, and Summer Street could all benefit from better biking systems.
Can wheelchairs be considered as a primary part of the plan - not separate or as an afterthought?

South Boston, given its huge rate of growth doesn't have the ample public transit that it needs. The neighborhood is at war with one another over parking but if we had more bus service during workday commutes or even a light rail up 1st street, we could alleviate the number of those who need a car.
When do you think we can get an actual light rail to replace the busses on the seaport silver line?
When will we have bike lanes in Southie?
Can we connect the Seaport to Backbay through Broadway?  There is an old unused track 61 that is dormant and could do the job.
Can we add some loop lines to connect our transportation system as seen in London or New York?
How will you guarantee that transit dependent people will have reliable service to jobs and opportunities?
Will there be more buses with more seats?

Can we put a trolley system along Broadway in Southie connecting City Point and Copley?  The #9 bus is always limited in efficiency by Boston traffic and the bus drivers are aggressive and demonstrate a high degree of road rage.  The bus system has outlived its relevancy in a growing South Boston.
Why is there not a subway stop further into Southie?
Why at Downtown Crossing on the Red Line there is only one direction to get to/from the Orange Line?
When will bike lanes connect the entire city?
Will the residents of South Boston's City Point neighborhood ever be able to take the T to the Southie Waterfront on a Sunday?  In other words, will the #7 bus ever run on Sunday??

IF the T has not been invested in enough to handle something as simple as the weather (hot or cold) especially snow (which is very usual Boston weather) THEN what drastic investments and changes will be made to the T for Boston to accommodate a complex public transportation situation fit for an Olympics?
Has the city considered water taxis to connect Boston's waterfront neighborhoods? Castle Island > Seaport > Financial > Charlestown?
Will the MBTA consider running more buses after rush hour?

Will you consider walkable e neighborhoods that satisfy the needs of transit dependent and low income people not just well off. Well it be like the old days when you good most of your every basic needs at affordable prices with out leaving your neighborhood and also not displace low income and transit dependent ?
What are the City's plans to connect the residents around the W. First Street corridor in South Boston with the downtown and the Seaport?
Will we reopen the discussion about installing bike lanes on Broadway in South Boston?
Will we stop forcing developers to include more offstreet parking than they would otherwise, which increases housing costs, air pollution, traffic, and demand for limited onstreet parking?
Will the city continue to reverse the highwayification trends of the 1950s and 60s, and reshape roads like Morrissey Blvd, Day Blvd, and Old Colony to make them work for people instead of cars?
Can we add buses in Boston for public transportation while also for sightseeing?
Can they drop you off anywhere you got to go? (By they, I mean bus drivers)
What about having shuttles that are express between train stations?
Why isn't there more parking in South Boston?
When and where will the roads/travel systems expand to be more extensive and efficient as in most major metro cities, i.e. LA, Miami, NYC?
Will the T come to East and South Boston?
Why is nothing connecting Seaport to surrounding areas?
Will they be running shuttle services (intra community) not just East/West?
Faster and smaller roads for bikes, skateboards, and small cars?
How can the elderly get around safely with the snow mountains?
When will emergency vehicles have better access on roads?
Can we have more buses or a better system for getting around Southie? Double what they are now.
When are we going to get more bike lanes?
Why is it impossible  to get from Southie to the North End?
Are we going to get more bike lanes?
Why aren't the southern neighborhoods connected by light rail? They're extending into Somerville but what about Mattapan, Dot, etc.?
When are we getting a circle line?
How can we get to the hospital or vet in an emergency if our cars are plowed in?
How will you clear up the mess that is I-93 between 5-7pm?
Will the T go to Seaport?
Will the T be more reliable and extend the lines?
When will I be able to bike to work, never having to mix with vehicle traffic?  (South Station to Government Center)
Can there be lower fees on holidays?
Is transportation going to be affordable for people who have low-income salaries?
Will public transportation ever be something that people can afford?
Can the MBTA change their fare system so that you pay different amounts based on how far you are taking the T? Think like the Washington DC metro system
Can we have some kind of free transportation to hospitals and medical appointments?
Why does the T keep increasing rates yet the trains keep breaking down more often?
When will Boston start charging for parking permits in congested neighborhoods?
When do school students get a bus cards for free?
Will South Boston get more bike lanes?
When will the MBTA further expand train services and better bus routes to Roxbury?

When building, are you going to consider the effect on pedestrians?  More sidewalks taken for curb cuts for garages and parking lots.  Because these cars need entrances and exits, snow is put on pedestrian ways. Are you going to take these issues into consideration when building?
Why are the buses in South Boston always so crowded?
Will transportation be more efficient, faster and cleaner?
During large snow storms, the city focus on cleaning the streets of snow, we need to show as much attention to the city sidewalks where most of the snow plowed ends up.
Could more one way roads, like the new plan recently implemented in South Boston, ease traffic congestion, improve snow removal, and make streets safer for bikers and pedestrians?
Do we want to be a city where City Hall allows people to claim public parking spaces as their own with pieces of trash, and enforce those claims through vandalism and personal violence?
How do we improve the bike lanes in the neighborhoods?
Can we do something about the traffic in the snow?
Will you ever make the Hubway year round?
How can we shop or use businesses when they don't shovel the snow?
Are there going to be better ways to park during snow storms?
How does the city allow for space markers to be put out before the snow?
Why do we still have 8ft snow banks a week after the storm? snow removal has been terrible.
Could you get more buses and trains so they won't be so packed?
Can we abolish the MBTA unions and finally update this archaic entity to actually provide some state of the art transportation as seen in Japan?
How are capital projects prioritized in Boston? (Are they by: number of people impacted, project costs, community needs, vocal residents, developer interests, etc.?)
Why are you stopping the buses for 8th and 9th graders?
Why don't they enforce live parking in bike lanes?
Why does the city take away the ability to drive and not provide any other alternative?
Who is the brains behind the MBTA decision-makers?
On streets with double parking, how can we develop a public process that might reasonably conclude with skinnier streets, bulb outs, and wider pedestrian and cycling areas?
In the future, will our transportation modes help to prevent childhood & adult obesity?

Why don't we use recycled materials to create new seating for trains? The blue seat covers are screaming for germs!  If we create flat, easy to clean surfaces, we could not only create sustainable seating, but operate in a more health-conscious manner as a city. Thank you!!
Will we be able to use jetpacks in Boston?
Why can't we install solar powered commuting pods as they are planning in Secaucus, New Jersey?
In 2030 there is likely to be an uber type system with autonomous electric cars.  Can the city integrate this into public transport systems? Like a high tech changing route bus system.
Can the city use on-demand transportation app ideas, like uber and bridj, to create dynamic and user-friendly buses that can change routes and pick ups based on customer needs?
NYC has some melter trucks that melt snow on the streets.  Why does Boston not have this technology yet, despite the fact we have more snow?
How about airline cable cars?
Will there be flying cars?
Why can't you track the buses by GPS?  The MBTA trip planner doesn't show accurate times.
Why not more agile/flex city vehicles/buses?
Will there be more modes of transportation?
When will we have hover cars?
How can we get more people out of their space wasting cars?
What are the plans to have more efficient service on green lines?
Instead of relying on everyone having a smartphone to check when the next bus is coming, why not install small tickers at each bus stop?

Can we please update Broadway Station as the population in the area has exsploded over the past 20 years? The station and streets can no longer handle the volume and there is plenty of State land to expand on.  Turing thus area into a business center would add revenues.

Why doesn't the T work when it snows out?  Snow is not new to Boston and for the T to be fundamentally crippled each time there is snow its unacceptable.  There's no accountability.  Who can we hold accountable for our completely antiquated and feeble public transportation system?  And if a little snow shuts us down how are we going to accommodate the Olympics?
If the T completely breaks down in the snow, how in the world will it handle the Olympics?
Will there be more busses in South Boston?
Is there a way to indicate that the next bus that's coming is full so you don't wait outside for it in the cold just so it can pass you by?
1. Will the buses start moving faster? 2. When do school students get a bus cards for free? 3. Who is the brains behind the MBTA decision-makers?"
Why does it take so long to get a parking permit from City Hall?
What can we do to make sure the bus drivers stop at all the bus stops?
When is the T going to stay open later than 1am?
Can the buses come more often in the winter?
Will they ever make the T and buses 24 hours a day?
Is the 47 bus ever going to be on time?
Can we get public transportation like MBTA to be on time?
What plans are there to increase safety for passengers?
Will there be more bike lanes that provide a safer ride to us?
In the future, will cyclists have to worry about their safety as much as we do now?

Why are cyclists not required to have license plates and be accountable for traffic violations?  Most of them (99%!) do not abide by the rules of the road yet motorists are expected to share the city streets with them.

Why are cyclists not required to have license plates and be accountable for traffic violations?  Most of them (99%!) do not abide by the rules of the road yet motorists are expected to share the city streets with them.
Why not privatize the MBTA?  If not that, train the current employees to be customer focused.

Why is there no accountability towards bicyclists?  We constantly try to find ways to improve their riding conditions and safety, but don't acknowledge that most cyclists fail to follow traffic rules.  Running through stop signs and stop lights, wearing headphones while riding their bikes on the road, and almost running into pedestrians because they pay no attention to their surroundings to name a few problems.  This isn't an isolated problem either; it's widespread.  I'm all for making road conditions safer for cyclists, but the solution must be a two-way street.  Cyclists must start being held accountable to traffic laws.

The future of Boston traffic should incorporate more automated rail and trolley systems instead of buses.  Buses are unsafe (bus drivers are extremely aggressive on the road in my experience)  and unreliable with Boston traffic.  Reduce the number of drivers we need with automated systems and the cost savings will pay off in the long term.
Will the bus drivers be nicer?

How can we reduce the amount of car ownership and the number of car trips in Boston, which will improve air quality, ease snow plowing/removal, increase ridership/support for the MBTA, and reduce injury, death, and aggravation?
Why not give tax credits to people who do not own cars?  Also, solar powered neon bright crosswalks and road lines.  Safety AND Function.
question
